conclusion: Analyze step-by-step to determine whether point O1 is to the right of point O.
The solid horizontal line is the boundary between air (above) and water (below).
Point A is in the air.
Point B is in the water.
Point O is where line AB intersects the air-water boundary.
O1 is another point on the boundary where the light beam actually enters the water.
The light follows path A → O1 → B.
When light moves from one medium to another, it refracts according to Snell's Law.
Snell's Law: n1 sinθ1 = n2 sinθ2.
n1 is the refractive index of the first medium (air).
n2 is the refractive index of the second medium (water).
θ1 is the angle of incidence.
θ2 is the angle of refraction.
Water has a higher refractive index than air.
When light travels from air to water, it bends toward the normal.
If light were to travel directly from A to B through point O, it would follow a straight line.
The light beam travels from A to point O1 on the boundary.
At O1, the light refracts and bends toward the normal.
The light continues to point B after refraction.
For the light to refract and still reach B, the entry point O1 must be different from O.
Given the bend is toward the normal, O1 must be positioned to the right of O.
Yes, point O1 is to the right of point O.
